text: has no storage though, so it would have to be connected to an external drive, or a docking station/NAS or something
Hmm… It seems like finding the optimal machine for a Plex Server is the most difficult part of this whole thing.
I was thinking that maybe I would just make an all-in-one media rig for the living room that would be able to support all my media needs such as acting as a Plex Server, Data Warehouse, and VR.
My “Dream Build” would come out to about $2,000 so there’s definitely some thinking that needs to go into this…
<https://smile.amazon.com/gp/registry/wishlist/1LJO2TZ4M5NLE/ref=nav_wishlist_lists_2>
But I would pretty much go balls to the walls with it
Then set that up with an array of WD MyBooks
This is a tough problem to solve. You have to think about economics(your money), performance, capability, versatility, etc…
And everything seems to be a tradeoff.

The Shield is a great option, but it doesn’t have any internal storage, really can’t encode more than 1 stream unless you get the full version, and will ultimately be a lot worse once we start getting 4k rips.
I almost just want to go balls to the walls with a $2,000 rig that’ll host everything, allow 4 1080p streams, let me play all of my steam games, and get into VR porn.
But damn, $2,000 would be annoying to spend on that…
Maybe next year bonus time…
If I still don’t have a shitton of debt upon my shoulders.
This is turning out to be a fun problem to solve though. How are you liking your Synology?

Haha damn yeah that thing is a beast. So far my set up is pretty good. Using the laptop I got from the auction at Zywave, has a decent processor and has been able to play everything I've watched so far just fine. All my media is stored on the synology server and I mapped the network drive on the laptop so plex references that
Got everything set up with accessing plex outside my network too with the vpn running which is nice
